not declared in this scope: This error occurs when you use a variable, function, or identifier that hasn't been declared or is out of scope. Common causes: missing include statements, typos in variable names, or using variables before declaration.
expected ';' before: This error indicates a missing semicolon. In C/C++, statements must end with a semicolon. Check the line before the error location.
cannot convert: This error occurs when trying to assign or convert between incompatible types. Check the types of variables and ensure they match or can be safely converted.
redefinition of: This error means you've declared the same identifier (variable, function, class) multiple times. Remove duplicate declarations or use different names.
undefined reference to: This is a linker error indicating that a function or variable is declared but not defined. Ensure all functions are implemented or link the necessary object files/libraries.
does not name a type: This error typically occurs when a type (class, struct, etc.) is used before it's defined, or when a required header file is missing.
invalid conversion from: This error indicates an attempt to convert between incompatible pointer or value types. Check type compatibility and use appropriate casts if needed.
